name: Optical Resolution Photoacoustic Microscopy
summary: Optical resolution photoacoustic microscopy (OR-PAM) is a high-resolution variant of photoacoustic imaging that achieves optical diffraction-limited lateral resolution (0.5-5 μm) by tightly focusing the excitation laser beam, unlike conventional photoacoustic tomography (PAT) where resolution is determined by acoustic wavelength (~100-500 μm). Pulsed laser light (ns-scale, typically 532-580 nm visible for heritage) is focused to a diffraction-limited spot on/within the sample; absorbed photons generate localized thermoelastic expansion → ultrasonic waves (tens of MHz) detected by a focused ultrasound transducer confocally aligned with laser focus. Raster scanning the co-focused laser-transducer pair across sample (XY) with depth scanning (Z focus adjustment) generates 3D images with optical lateral resolution (~1-3 μm, determined by laser NA) and acoustic axial resolution (~15-50 μm, determined by ultrasound frequency 20-80 MHz). Penetration depth limited by optical scattering (50-1000 μm depending on sample transparency, wavelength). Heritage applications—highly specialized and emerging—include microscale pigment mapping in paint cross-sections (identify individual pigment grains 1-50 μm with optical absorption contrast), organic layer visualization (binder distributions, glazes, varnishes distinguishable by absorption differences), and subsurface imaging of translucent materials (parchment fibers, textile structures, coral/shell microstructure) where conventional optical microscopy fails due to scattering but OR-PAM penetrates via acoustic detection.
keyApplications: Pigment grain mapping in paint cross-sections (1-5 μm resolution, distinguish co-located pigments by absorption)
Organic layer visualization (binder/glaze absorption contrast, 10-100 μm depth)
Translucent material subsurface imaging (parchment fibers, paper structure, textile weave at depth)
Biological materials (coral, shell, bone microstructure; heritage natural history specimens)
Micro-underdrawing detection (ink lines 5-20 μm beneath 50-200 μm paint layers)
3D vascular-like networks (organic adhesive penetration, consolidant distribution in porous substrates)
typicalTimePerMeasurement: Minutes to hours (100×100 μm area @ 1 μm step = 10,000 points × 0.1 s = 17 min; 1×1 mm = 3 hours)

costRange.instrument: $150,000-$400,000 (research OR-PAM system: pulsed laser $50-100K + microscope + ultrasound + scanning stages)

fundamentalPhysics.principle: OR-PAM differs from acoustic-resolution PAT in that lateral resolution is determined by optical focus (diffraction-limited laser spot ~λ/2NA ≈ 0.5-5 μm) rather than acoustic focus (~λ_acoustic/2 ≈ 50-300 μm at MHz frequencies). Tightly focused laser pulse (5-10 ns, 0.1-1 μJ energy at sample) → absorption in diffraction-limited volume (~1-10 μm³) → transient heating (mK) → thermoelastic expansion → spherical acoustic wave (broadband, 1-100 MHz content, peak at ~20-50 MHz depending on absorber size). Ultrasound transducer (focused, confocally aligned with laser spot, center frequency 20-80 MHz) detects pressure wave. Time-of-flight encodes depth (axial position z); lateral position (x,y) encoded by scan coordinates. Raster scan generates 3D volume A(x,y,z) where A ∝ μ_a (absorption coefficient, molecular contrast). Resolution: lateral ~1.2λ/NA_optical (e.g., 532 nm, NA=0.5 → ~1.3 μm); axial ~0.88·c_s/BW_acoustic (e.g., 50 MHz center, 60% BW=30 MHz → ~44 μm if c_s=1500 m/s). Penetration: optical scattering-limited (~1 mean free path ≈ 100 μm - 1 mm depending on sample turbidity, wavelength).
fundamentalPhysics.physicalPhenomenon: Same photoacoustic mechanism as PAT (absorption → heat → pressure), but geometric difference: OR-PAM uses optical focusing for lateral resolution (requires focusing to depth of interest → depth-dependent resolution if heterogeneous media), whereas acoustic-resolution PAT uses acoustic focusing (uniform resolution regardless of optical scattering but coarser ~100 μm). OR-PAM achieves microscopy-level resolution (comparable to confocal/multiphoton microscopy) while maintaining absorption contrast (complementary to fluorescence-based microscopy which shows fluorophores, OR-PAM shows absorbers: pigments, melanin, hemoglobin in biomedical, carbon/dyes in heritage). Confocal alignment critical: laser excitation volume and ultrasound detection volume overlap → maximum signal. Misalignment →signal loss, resolution degradation.

variables.meaning: lateral (XY) resolution, FWHM of point-spread function
laser wavelength (532 nm typical visible, 700-900 nm NIR)
numerical aperture of focusing objective (0.3-0.9 typical; 0.5 → d~1.3 μm @ 532 nm)
sound speed in medium (1500 m/s water/soft tissue, 2000-4000 m/s paints/wood)
acoustic bandwidth (20-80 MHz typical, fractional BW ~60% → BW ≈ 0.6·f_center)
effective imaging depth (~1 transport mean free path)
focal volume (smaller for tight focus → fewer molecules → weaker signal but better resolution; trade-off)

fundamentalPhysics.interactionDepth: Depth range determined by optical penetration (laser must reach focus depth, signal photons return for detection). In clear media (water, oil, transparent resins): 1-2 mm penetration (limited by absorption, minimal scattering). In scattering media (paint, tissue, paper): 50-500 μm typical (1-2 transport mean free paths; beyond this, light diffuses, focus blurs, lateral resolution degrades). Axially: acoustic signal propagates from absorber to surface transducer; low attenuation in soft materials → mm-cm range detectable (but signal weaker with depth due to geometric spreading + frequency-dependent attenuation α~f² → higher freq 50-80 MHz attenuates faster, practical depth 500 μm - 2 mm). Optimal OR-PAM: <500 μm depth for best lateral resolution (optical focus maintained); 500 μm - 1 mm acceptable (degraded resolution); >1 mm transitions to acoustic-resolution regime (scattering dominates, loses optical resolution).
fundamentalPhysics.spatialResolution: Lateral: 0.5-5 μm (optical diffraction-limited). Typical heritage systems: 1-3 μm @ 532 nm (NA 0.4-0.6). Higher NA (0.8-1.0) → 0.5-0.8 μm but shorter working distance (<500 μm), sample access limited. Trade-off: resolution vs working distance (high NA = short WD). Axial: 15-50 μm (acoustic bandwidth-limited). 50 MHz center, 60% BW → ~45 μm @ c_s=1500 m/s. Higher freq (80-100 MHz) → 20-30 μm but more attenuation (shallower penetration <500 μm). Lower freq (20-30 MHz) → 60-100 μm axial but deeper (>1 mm). Limiting factors: Lateral - optical NA (high NA needs short WD → access issues for thick samples; immersion objectives help). Axial - ultrasound frequency (higher f → better axial res. but attenuation α∝f² limits depth). Depth-dependent lateral resolution (scattering blurs optical focus at depth → resolution degrades beyond ~1 scattering mean free path). Confocal alignment (laser-transducer overlap critical; misalignment blurs image, reduces SNR). Sample heterogeneity (refractive index variations → optical aberrations, focus distortion).
fundamentalPhysics.detectionLimit: Absorption coefficient μ_a ~ 0.1-1 mm⁻¹ detectable (weakly absorbing features). Strong absorbers (pigment grains μ_a ~ 10-100 mm⁻¹) easily detected. Concentration: ~0.1-1 wt% pigment in binder (depends on absorption cross-section, focal volume ~1-10 μm³ contains 10¹²-10¹⁴ molecules if 1 wt% → sufficient signal). Single-cell sensitivity in biomedical (melanin in melanocytes, RBCs); heritage: single pigment grain 1-5 μm diameter. Dynamic range: 10³-10⁴ in absorption (image strong pigments + weak binder absorption in same volume if multi-wavelength). Signal-to-noise: SNR 20-100:1 typical for pigmented layers. Surface features (z=0-50 μm): SNR 50-100. Depth (z=200-500 μm): SNR 10-30 (signal weaker due to optical attenuation, geometric spreading). Averaging improves: 10-100 pulses per pixel (√N SNR gain).

instrumentation.source: Pulsed laser, ns-scale: Nd:YAG (532 nm doubled, common for pigments), dye laser (tunable 400-700 nm), or OPO (700-1200 nm NIR for deeper penetration). Pulse duration: 5-10 ns (stress confinement for efficient photoacoustic generation). Repetition rate: 1-10 kHz typical (fast scanning; vs. 10-100 Hz PAT, OR-PAM needs high rep rate for reasonable acquisition time). Energy per pulse: 10-1000 nJ at sample (sub-μJ; focused to μm spot → fluence 1-100 mJ/cm² safe for heritage). Wavelength: 532 nm standard (strong absorption by most pigments, dyes); 580 nm (oxy-hemoglobin peak, if biomedical); 700-900 nm (NIR, deeper penetration, lower scattering). Energy range: 2.3 eV (532 nm) to 1.4 eV (900 nm). Power range: Average power: 10-1000 μW (energy per pulse × rep rate; e.g., 100 nJ × 10 kHz = 1 mW). Peak power: 10-100 W (100 nJ / 10 ns = 10 W peak). Safe for samples: fluence <100 mJ/cm² surface, <20 mJ/cm² if photosensitive.
instrumentation.detector: Focused ultrasound transducer: single-element, spherically focused, center frequency 20-80 MHz. Piezoelectric (PZT, LiNbO₃) or PVDF. Needle hydrophone alternative (unfocused but small aperture, research). Spectral range: Acoustic: 5-100 MHz sensitive range (transducer bandwidth typically 50-80% fractional BW; e.g., 50 MHz center → 20-80 MHz BW). Efficiency: Sensitivity: ~0.1-1 V/MPa (50 MHz transducers). Noise floor: ~1-10 kPa (acoustic pressure). Detect PA signals 10 kPa - 1 MPa (dynamic range 10⁴). Time resolution: Sampling rate: 100-500 MHz ADC (Nyquist: sample ≥2× highest frequency; 80 MHz signal → 160 MHz minimum, typically 200-500 MHz for oversampling). Temporal precision ~5-20 ns (determines axial resolution: 10 ns × 1500 m/s = 15 μm depth precision).
instrumentation.optics: Beam delivery and focusing optics: mirrors, lenses, microscope objective (NA 0.3-0.6 typical heritage; 0.8-1.0 for high-res but short WD). Confocal alignment system (dichroic mirror or beam combiner to co-align laser and acoustic foci; critical component). Scanning stages: high-precision XYZ (PI, Thorlabs, Newport; 0.1-1 μm encoder resolution; $20-50K for 3-axis motorized). Acoustic coupling: water bath or ultrasound gel (transducer couples to sample via liquid; acoustic impedance matching). Beam path: Laser → beam expander (collimate to fill objective back aperture) → dichroic/combiner → microscope objective (focus to sample, focal spot ~1-3 μm diameter) → sample (absorbs, generates PA wave) → acoustic wave propagates to transducer (confocally positioned, focal zone overlaps laser focus, typically 5-10 mm focal length, ~100 μm focal diameter acoustic) → transducer converts pressure → voltage → preamplifier → ADC → computer. Scan: motorized XY stage moves sample (or scan mirrors/galvos move laser beam if fast-axis scanning), Z-stage adjusts focus depth. Focusing: Critical: laser tightly focused (high NA objective, 1-3 μm spot). Transducer moderately focused (100-500 μm acoustic focal zone, confocal with laser). Confocal alignment: laser focus (optical) and transducer focus (acoustic) overlap in 3D → maximum signal. Misalignment 10s of μm → signal loss 50-90%. Alignment procedure: image point absorber (carbon particle, gold bead), adjust transducer XYZ, maximize PA signal.
criticalComponents: High-rep-rate pulsed laser (kHz, not Hz; OR-PAM scanning ~10⁴-10⁶ pixels → kHz necessary for reasonable acquisition time)
High-NA objective + ultrasound transducer confocal assembly (custom-built in most systems; commercial OR-PAM rare; requires precision alignment, waterproof/gel-compatible optics)
Precision scanning stages (0.1-1 μm step size for 1-3 μm resolution imaging; backlash <0.5 μm; encoder feedback)
High-speed ADC (200-500 MHz to capture 50-80 MHz acoustic transients; 8-12 bit sufficient dynamic range)
Confocal alignment stability (vibration, thermal drift → misalignment → signal loss; requires stable platform, temperature control)
instrumentation.typicalConfiguration: Heritage research OR-PAM (prototype, <5 worldwide 2025): Nd:YAG laser (532 nm, 5 ns, 5 kHz rep rate, 10 mW average = 2 μJ/pulse) → fiber delivery or free-space → 10× objective (NA 0.3, WD 10 mm, spot size ~2 μm) → sample in water bath. Focused transducer (50 MHz center, 30 MHz BW, 6 mm focal length, 80 μm focal zone) positioned 45° to optical axis (side-view geometry; transducer at angle avoids blocking laser path). Confocal: overlap laser + acoustic foci (adjusted via translation stages). Scanning: motorized XY stage (PI M-111.1DG, 25 mm travel, 0.1 μm resolution), Z-manual or motorized (focus depth adjustment). ADC: 250 MHz sampling (NI PXIe-5164), 10 bit. Coupling: deionized water bath (sample submerged or membrane-coupled if moisture-sensitive). Computer: MATLAB real-time acquisition + display (hilbert envelope detection, log compression, colormap). Typical scan: 500×500 μm area @ 1 μm step = 250,000 pixels × 0.2 ms per pixel = 50 s per depth slice; Z-stack 10 slices (50 μm spacing) = 8 min total. Alternative NIR OR-PAM (under development): OPO 700-900 nm tunable (deeper penetration, wood/parchment), 80 MHz transducer (higher axial res. ~25 μm, but <500 μm depth), similar scan times.

commercialSystems.name: OR-PAM research system
commercialSystems.notes: 532 nm, 5 kHz, 50 MHz transducer, motorized XYZ scan. Designed for mouse/small animal imaging but adaptable for flat heritage samples (paint cross-sections). Rare, limited availability. Estimated cost: $300,000-$500,000 (if available outside biomedical).

commercialSystems.name: Custom heritage OR-PAM
commercialSystems.notes: OR-PAM systems custom-built by research groups (biomedical focus: Caltech, Washington University, Singapore). Heritage applications: TU Delft, UCL, National Gallery (prototypes). Component costs for self-build: $150,000-$400,000. None commercial for heritage as of 2025.

samplePreparation: Micro-samples (paint cross-sections 100-500 μm thick × 1-5 mm length) or intact objects if accessible (thin: <1 mm thick for through-transmission coupling; flat surface for reflection mode).

Cross-sections: embed in polyester resin, polish to 0.25 μm finish (flat, smooth → optimal optical focus), mount on glass slide (1 mm thick), immerse in water bath or apply ultrasound gel (acoustic coupling).

Intact samples: position horizontally, apply gel layer (3-5 mm thick) between sample and transducer, or submerge in water bath (if moisture-tolerant). Secure sample (prevent motion during scan; sub-μm movement blurs image).

Polished surface preferred (cross-sections: 0.25 μm diamond paste final polish). Rough surfaces acceptable but degrade optical focus (scattering at interface), reduce lateral resolution to ~5-10 μm. No coating needed (vs. SEM; OR-PAM works on uncoated samples, advantage for organics).

Contamination concerns: Surface contamination (dust, fingerprints) absorbs laser → spurious PA signals. Clean with air duster, ethanol wipe (if sample tolerates) before imaging. Water/gel absorption (moisture-sensitive samples: unvarnished paint, soluble media → use minimal gel or membrane barrier; test area first). Optical aberrations (refractive index mismatch: resin embedding n~1.5, water coupling n~1.33 → spherical aberration if objective not corrected; use water-immersion objectives or index-matched coupling fluid n~1.5 for resin samples).
methodology.measurementProtocol:
**Step 1: System Alignment and Calibration** (30-60 minutes daily; 5-10 min for check/realignment subsequent sessions)

Laser: Warm up (10-20 min, thermal stability). Verify output: energy meter at sample position (100-500 nJ/pulse typical). Wavelength check (spectrometer or accept factory calibration ±1 nm).

Confocal alignment: Critical step. Mount point absorber (10 μm carbon particle on glass slide, or gold nanoparticle dried on coverslip). Position under objective, focus laser (visible spot via camera if 532 nm). Fire laser, adjust transducer XYZ position (6-axis manipulator: 3 translation + 3 rotation typical) until PA signal maximized (oscilloscope monitors signal amplitude). Maximize: adjust X (lateral to laser axis), Y (perpendicular), Z (depth, along acoustic axis). Typical signal: 10-100 mV for 100 nJ pulse on 10 μm carbon at optimal alignment. Misalignment → <1 mV. Record optimal transducer position (encoder readings), recheck daily (thermal drift may shift alignment ±10 μm overnight).

Sound speed calibration: Measure with known phantom (e.g., two parallel absorbing lines separated by known distance d = 50 μm in Z). Image, measure time-of-flight Δt between lines, calculate c_s = d / Δt. Adjust c_s setting in software (default 1500 m/s water; resin-embedded samples ~1800-2000 m/s, adjust for accurate depth scaling).

**Step 2: Sample Mounting and Coupling** (10-20 minutes)

Mount sample on stage (XY scanning stage, sample stationary if beam-scanning OR-PAM). Cross-section: place polished surface facing objective (face-up if inverted microscope, face-down if upright). Apply coupling medium: Water bath: Submerge sample in shallow dish (10-20 mm water depth), transducer enters water from side/top (avoid bubbles trapped under transducer face → blocks ultrasound; tilt transducer, tap gently to dislodge bubbles). Gel coupling: Apply generous ultrasound gel (5 mm layer on sample surface), lower transducer into gel (ensure contact, no air pockets). Verify coupling quality: send ultrasound pulse (transducer transmit mode, if available), observe reflection from sample surface (strong echo = good coupling, weak = air gap → reapply gel, remove bubbles). Position objective: lower until sample in focus (camera view, white light illumination if available, or IR viewer for NIR lasers). Working distance: NA 0.3-0.5 objectives typically 5-15 mm WD (adequate for sample + coupling layer). High-NA 0.8-1.0: <1 mm WD (requires thin coverslip + immersion, challenging for cross-sections). Focus depth: initially at sample surface (Z=0), then adjust for subsurface imaging (increment Z in software, objective/stage moves).

**Step 3: Scan Parameter Optimization** (15-30 minutes, iterate to optimize)

Define scan area (XY ROI): locate feature of interest via optical imaging (camera, brightfield), mark bounds in software (e.g., 500×500 μm for single pigment grain layer analysis, or 2×2 mm for full cross-section). Set step size: match to lateral resolution (~0.5-1× spot size for Nyquist sampling; 2 μm resolution → 1-2 μm step size). Smaller steps oversample (longer scan, no resolution gain); larger steps undersample (aliasing, missed features).

Laser energy: Test single pixel (fire 10 pulses, measure PA signal amplitude). If weak (<10× noise, SNR <10:1): increase laser energy (up to safe limit ~100 mJ/cm² surface fluence; calculate from pulse energy and spot size), verify no sample damage (no color change, smoke, if organic). If saturates ADC (signal clips at +/- full scale): reduce energy or increase ADC gain range.

Averaging: Acquire multiple pulses per pixel (1-100), average PA waveforms (√N SNR improvement). Trade-off: averaging improves SNR but increases acquisition time (10× average → 10× slower). Typical: 10-50 averages for deep/weak features, 1-10 for strong surface features.

Depth range: Set time window for ADC (Z_max = c_s × t_window / 2; e.g., 10 μs window, c_s=1500 m/s → 7.5 mm depth range; only need ~1 mm for cross-sections → 1.3 μs adequate, reduces data size). Adjust delay (trigger to acquisition start) if surface echo arrives after trigger (typical: 5-10 μs delay for transducer 10 mm from sample).

**Step 4: 2D Scan Acquisition (Single Depth Slice)** (5-60 minutes per 2D slice, depending on area, step size, averaging)

Initiate XY raster scan (software-controlled motorized stages). At each (x,y) position: (1) Stage moves to position (1-10 ms settling time, encoder feedback ensures arrival ±0.1 μm). (2) Laser fires N pulses (N = averaging factor, 1-100). (3) ADC captures acoustic waveform each pulse (200-500 MHz sampling, 500-5000 points, 2-10 μs duration per waveform). (4) Waveforms averaged (if N>1). (5) PA signal envelope extracted (Hilbert transform: converts RF oscillation → amplitude envelope). (6) Peak amplitude (or integral) recorded as pixel intensity I(x,y). (7) Stage moves to next position. Scan pattern: raster (serpentine: →→← to minimize backlash) or spiral. Typical speeds: 100-1000 pixels/s depending on stage acceleration, laser rep rate, averaging. Real-time display: software shows image as it acquires (update every row or every N pixels). Monitor quality: if signal drops midway (coupling lost, transducer moved), stop, recouple, resume. Total time example: 500×500 pixels @ 2 μm step = 250,000 pixels. Laser 5 kHz, 10 averages → 2 ms per pixel → 500 s = 8 min per slice. 1×1 mm @ 1 μm = 1 million pixels → 33 min per slice (if 2 ms per pixel).

**Step 5: 3D Volumetric Imaging (Z-Stack)** (30 minutes - 3 hours, for 5-20 depth slices)

To image 3D volume (not just surface): repeat 2D scans at multiple depths. Z-scanning methods: (1) Objective focus adjustment: Motorized Z-stage moves objective (or sample stage) to change focal depth. Increment Z (20-100 μm steps, match to acoustic axial resolution ~40 μm), repeat XY scan at each depth. (2) Acoustic time-gating: Keep optical focus fixed, extract different depth ranges from same waveform (early time window = shallow, late = deep; depth resolution limited by acoustic BW ~40 μm). Software processes: extract amplitude at multiple time delays → multiple depth slices from single XY scan (faster than mechanical Z-scan but lower depth resolution). Typical Z-stack: 5-20 slices, 20-50 μm spacing, total depth range 100-1000 μm (depends on penetration). Acquisition time: N_slices × time per 2D scan; e.g., 10 slices × 10 min = 100 min = 1.7 hr for 3D volume 500×500×200 μm³. Data size: 500×500 pixels × 10 slices × 2 bytes (16-bit amplitude) = 5 MB per volume (small; minimal storage issue).

**Step 6: Multi-Wavelength Imaging (Optional, Spectroscopic OR-PAM)** (2-10 hours, for 5-10 wavelengths × 3D volume)

To identify materials via absorption spectra: repeat 3D volume at multiple wavelengths (e.g., 532, 560, 580, 600 nm if tunable dye laser or OPO). At each λ: full XYZ scan → one 3D volume A(x,y,z,λ). Wavelengths chosen to span absorption features (pigment spectra: vermilion peaks ~500-600 nm, ultramarine 590 nm, ochres broad 400-700 nm). Typically 5-10 wavelengths (balance spectral info vs. time). Analysis: At each voxel (x,y,z), measure A(λ₁), A(λ₂), ..., A(λ_N). Spectral unmixing: fit to linear combination of reference spectra (pigment basis set) → concentration maps for each pigment (separate co-located grains). Acquisition time: N_wavelengths × time per volume; e.g., 5 wavelengths × 1 hr = 5 hr total. Requires tunable laser (OPO, dye laser; Nd:YAG 532 nm only = single-wavelength, no unmixing, but faster).

**Step 7: Data Processing and Image Reconstruction** (10-30 minutes per dataset)

Raw data: 3D or 4D array (X × Y × time samples, or X × Y × Z if depth-resolved, or X × Y × Z × λ if multi-wavelength). Preprocessing: (1) Bandpass filter: RF waveforms contain transducer frequency content (5-100 MHz); apply digital filter (e.g., 10-80 MHz bandpass for 50 MHz transducer, Butterworth 4th order) → remove DC drift + high-freq noise. (2) Hilbert transform: extract envelope from RF signal (acoustic oscillation → amplitude envelope, represents local pressure maximum ∝ absorption). (3) Log compression: display log(A) instead of A (compress dynamic range 10⁴ → 60 dB, reveal faint features alongside strong). (4) Depth correction (optional): compensate acoustic attenuation + geometric spreading (multiply signal by e^(αz) · z², where z = depth; typically α~0.5 dB/(cm·MHz), z in mm). Reconstruction: For single-focus OR-PAM, reconstruction is straightforward (each pixel = one position + depth directly encoded). Unlike PAT (requires inverse problem solving), OR-PAM is direct imaging (confocal detection → point-by-point mapping). Visualization: Load into software (ImageJ, Amira, MATLAB). 2D images: display as grayscale or false-color (absorption intensity). 3D volumes: volume rendering, maximum intensity projection (MIP), or slice-by-slice. Image enhancement: Gaussian smoothing (σ=1-2 pixels, reduce noise), histogram equalization (auto-contrast), or median filter (remove speckle).

typicalParameters.notes: 532 nm (Nd:YAG doubled): strong pigment absorption, cheap laser. 580 nm: oxy-Hb biomedical. 700-900 nm NIR: deeper penetration (lower scattering), but weaker pigment absorption.
Focused to 2-3 μm spot → fluence 10-100 mJ/cm². Higher energy → better SNR but damage risk. <100 mJ/cm² safe for most heritage. Test on edge/sacrificial area.
Higher rate → faster scanning (critical for large areas). 1 kHz: 1 ms per pixel minimum. 10 kHz: 0.1 ms per pixel (but stage settling, averaging add time).
NA 0.5: ~1.3 μm lateral res. @ 532 nm, 5-10 mm WD. High NA 0.8-1.0: 0.7-0.8 μm res. but <1 mm WD (immersion needed, challenging for cross-sections).
50 MHz: ~45 μm axial res., 500 μm - 1 mm penetration. 20-30 MHz: 70-100 μm res., >1 mm depth. 80 MHz: 25-30 μm res., <500 μm depth.
Match lateral resolution (0.5-1× spot diameter for Nyquist). 2 μm res. → 1-2 μm step. Smaller oversamples (longer, no gain), larger undersamples (miss features).
Improves SNR √N. 10× average → 3.2× SNR. Weak signals (depth, low absorption): 50-100. Strong surface: 5-10. Trade-off: time.
Nyquist: ≥2× max frequency. 80 MHz signal → 160 MHz minimum. 250-500 MHz typical (oversampling, margin, captures transients).
Z_max = c_s·t/2. 10 μs @ 1500 m/s = 7.5 mm depth. Cross-sections <1 mm thick → 2-3 μs adequate (reduces data size, processing time).

methodology.calibration:
Standards: Point absorber (10 μm carbon particle, gold nanoparticle on slide; confocal alignment, PSF measurement). Resolution target (USAF 1951 or custom: parallel carbon lines 1-10 μm spacing; verify lateral resolution). Depth phantom (known absorbers at multiple depths: 50, 100, 200 μm in agar or resin; verify axial resolution, sound speed). Absorption phantom (pigment suspensions at known concentrations: μ_a calibration if quantitative needed).

Frequency: Daily: confocal alignment check (point absorber, maximize signal, record transducer position). Weekly: resolution test (USAF target or line phantom, measure PSF, compare to spec: lateral ≤3 μm, axial ≤50 μm). Monthly: full calibration (sound speed, depth scaling, energy stability).

Procedure: Confocal alignment: Mount 10 μm carbon particle on glass slide, submerge in water. Focus laser (visible spot, or IR viewer). Fire laser (low energy, 100 nJ), observe PA signal (oscilloscope or ADC live view). Adjust transducer XYZ (6-axis manipulator), maximize signal amplitude (100 mV typical optimum, <10 mV if misaligned). Iterate: X (lateral), Y (perpendicular), Z (depth, along acoustic axis). Record final position (software saves encoder coordinates), apply as reference. Re-check daily (thermal drift ±10 μm overnight). Lateral resolution: Image USAF target (Group 7, Element 6 = 2.19 μm line pairs), or custom parallel lines (2-5 μm spacing, carbon ink on glass). Measure modulation transfer function (MTF: signal modulation vs. spatial frequency) or directly measure smallest resolved lines. If resolution degraded (>3 μm when spec 2 μm), check: objective (dirty, damaged?), confocal alignment (re-optimize), laser focus (aberrations? refractive index mismatch?).
qualityControl: Confocal alignment optimal (test on point absorber daily; signal >80% of maximum recorded)
Lateral resolution within spec (USAF target or line phantom: resolve 2-3 μm features if NA 0.5 @ 532 nm)
Axial resolution within spec (depth phantom: measure FWHM of point absorber in depth, <50 μm for 50 MHz transducer)
No sample damage (visual inspection post-scan; if discoloration, blistering, reduce laser energy)
Image artifacts minimal (streaking, banding, noise; check coupling, stage motion, electronic interference)

Common artifacts: Weak/absent signal (confocal misalignment, acoustic coupling failed, laser not firing, sample non-absorbing at wavelength) → Re-align confocal, verify coupling, check laser, test with known absorber, change wavelength if sample transparent. Streaking artifacts (stage motion issues, electronic noise, laser energy fluctuation) → Check stage motion smoothness, isolate ground loops, stabilize laser. Depth distortion (sound speed setting incorrect, heterogeneous c_s) → Measure c_s, adjust software setting, compare to cross-section microscopy. Blurred image (defocus, refractive index mismatch, scattering, confocal misalignment) → Refocus, index matching, reduce scattering, re-align confocal. Surface clutter (surface absorption, acoustic reflection) → Time-gating, wavelength selection, clean surface.

dataAnalysis.rawDataFormat: File formats: TIFF stack (X×Y slices, 16-bit grayscale, ImageJ-compatible; typical). HDF5 (large 4D volumes: X×Y×Z×λ, efficient compression). MAT (MATLAB: raw RF data + metadata, processing scripts). Binary + header (custom: raw ADC samples, separate text header with acquisition parameters). Data structure: 2D image: X×Y pixels × 2 bytes (16-bit amplitude, 0-65535). Typical: 500×500 pixels = 500 KB. 3D volume: X×Y×Z × 2 bytes; 500×500×20 slices = 10 MB. Multi-wavelength 4D: X×Y×Z×λ; 500×500×20×5 wavelengths = 50 MB. Typical file size: Single 2D slice: 0.5-2 MB (500×500 to 1000×1000 pixels). 3D volume: 10-100 MB (5-50 slices). Multi-wavelength: 50-500 MB (5-10 wavelengths). Manageable (cf. PAT raw RF data GB-scale).
preprocessing: Bandpass filtering (RF waveforms): Apply digital filter (Butterworth, Chebyshev, 10-80 MHz for 50 MHz transducer) to raw acoustic signals. Removes DC drift (<1 MHz), low-freq motion artifacts, high-freq electronic noise (>100 MHz). Improves SNR ~2-3×. Software: MATLAB (butter, filtfilt), Python (scipy.signal), LabVIEW real-time.

Hilbert transform (envelope detection): Convert RF oscillation (AC signal ±V at MHz frequency) → amplitude envelope (positive, slowly-varying, represents local pressure maximum). Standard photoacoustic processing. Hilbert transform = analytic signal, magnitude = envelope. Software: MATLAB (hilbert), Python (scipy.signal.hilbert), ImageJ (plugin).

Log compression: Display log₁₀(amplitude) or 20·log₁₀ (dB scale). Compresses dynamic range 10⁴ (80 dB) → visible in single image. Reveals faint features (binder absorption) alongside strong (pigments) without saturation. Standard in ultrasound imaging. Software: All visualization tools (ImageJ, Amira, MATLAB).

Depth correction (TGC, time-gain compensation): Compensate signal attenuation with depth: multiply by e^(αz)·z^n (α = acoustic attenuation, n=1-2 geometric spreading). Makes deep signals comparable to surface. Optional (may amplify noise at depth); use if depth >500 μm. Software: MATLAB, Python (custom scripts).

Background subtraction: Acquire 'blank' image (no laser, or laser on non-absorbing area → acoustic noise only). Subtract from sample images → removes electronic baseline, coherent noise. Improves contrast ~10-20%. Software: ImageJ (Process → Math → Subtract), MATLAB.
dataAnalysis.analysisWorkflow:
**Step 1: Visual Inspection**

Load 2D image or 3D volume into viewer (ImageJ, Amira, Horos). Adjust window/level (contrast, brightness) to reveal features. Identify: high-absorption regions (bright = pigment grains, dyes, inks), low-absorption (dark = lead white, binders, voids). Check artifacts (streaks, blurring, noise; see QC section if present).

**Step 2: Feature Segmentation**

Delineate regions of interest (pigment grains, layers, structures). Methods: (1) Manual (draw ROIs in ImageJ, Amira; slow but accurate). (2) Thresholding (intensity >threshold = feature; iterative adjustment). (3) Automated (watershed, region-growing, or ML-based; U-Net trained on labeled OR-PAM images → automatic segmentation; research-level). For pigment grains: threshold + particle analysis (ImageJ Analyze Particles: filters by size 1-50 μm², counts, measures areas).

**Step 3: Quantitative Measurements**

Extract metrics: Pigment grain size: Measure diameter or area (ImageJ ROI tools, Analyze → Measure). Compare size distributions (vermilion 5-20 μm natural, <5 μm synthetic → dating). Layer thickness: Measure Z-extent of absorption band (depth profile, FWHM). Accuracy ±20 μm (limited by axial resolution). Absorption intensity: Mean pixel value in ROI (proportional to μ_a if calibrated; otherwise relative). Compare pigment types (vermilion 5-10× more absorbing than ochre at 532 nm). Spatial distribution: Centroid positions, nearest-neighbor distances (pigment mixing analysis: clustered vs. uniformly mixed).

**Step 4: Depth Profiling**

Extract 1D profiles A(z) at selected (x,y) positions (line tool perpendicular to surface through 3D volume). Plot absorption vs. depth: peaks indicate absorbing layers (pigment, underdrawing), valleys indicate transparent (binder, ground). Measure: peak positions (layer depths ±20 μm), peak widths (layer thicknesses), peak amplitudes (relative concentrations).

**Step 5: Spectroscopic Analysis (if multi-wavelength)**

At each voxel, extract absorption spectrum A(λ). Compare to reference pigment spectra (library: vermilion, ochre, ultramarine, etc.). Spectral unmixing: linear least-squares fit A(λ) = Σ_i c_i·ε_i(λ), solve for concentrations c_i. Generate concentration maps (e.g., c_vermilion(x,y,z), c_ochre(x,y,z)). Separate co-located pigments (OR-PAM spatial resolution resolves grains, spectroscopic resolves overlapping absorption if adjacent grains <1 μm apart).

**Step 6: Correlation with Other Techniques**

Co-register OR-PAM with: (1) Optical microscopy: Overlay OR-PAM absorption map on brightfield image (same cross-section, register via fiducial marks, software alignment). Correlate absorption with color (red = vermilion = high 532 nm absorption). (2) SEM-EDS: Register OR-PAM (molecular, absorption) with EDS (elemental, Hg→vermilion, Fe→ochre). Confirm IDs (Hg + high absorption + red color = vermilion). (3) Raman: OR-PAM identifies grain locations, Raman analyzes specific grains (molecular structure, polymorph). Complementary: OR-PAM fast wide-field, Raman slow point-by-point but definitive. (4) FTIR: OR-PAM pigments, FTIR binders (organics). Combined: complete composition (pigment + binder per layer).

softwareTools.name: ImageJ/Fiji
softwareTools.notes: Open-source. Visualization (2D, 3D volume viewer), ROI analysis, particle counting, measurements, image processing (filters, math operations). Standard for microscopy, compatible with OR-PAM. Cost: Free.

softwareTools.name: MATLAB
softwareTools.notes: Commercial. Acquisition control (instrument communication, DAQ triggering), real-time processing (Hilbert, log compression, display), custom analysis scripts, spectroscopic unmixing. Cost: $2,500 academic, $5,000 commercial.

softwareTools.name: Amira
softwareTools.notes: Commercial. Advanced 3D visualization, segmentation (interactive, semi-automated), quantitative analysis (volume, surface area, distances), registration (multi-modal co-alignment). Cost: $10,000-$20,000.

softwareTools.name: Python (NumPy, SciPy, scikit-image, napari)
softwareTools.notes: Open-source. Custom processing (scripting), ML-based segmentation (TensorFlow, PyTorch), 3D visualization (napari, Mayavi), automation. Flexible, requires programming. Cost: Free.

softwareTools.name: Horos (Mac)
softwareTools.notes: Open-source. Medical imaging viewer (DICOM), 3D rendering, MPR (multi-planar reconstruction). Works with OR-PAM volumes if exported as DICOM. Cost: Free.

dataAnalysis.interpretationGuidelines: OR-PAM image = absorption coefficient map A(x,y,z), where A ∝ μ_a (proportional, not absolute unless calibrated). Brightness interpretation: Bright pixels (high A) = strong absorbers at excitation wavelength (pigments: vermilion, ochre, carbon black, dyes at 532 nm; oxy-Hb in biomedical). Dark pixels (low A) = weak/non-absorbers (lead white, barium sulfate, transparent binders NIR-transparent). Spatial patterns: Individual grains resolved (1-50 μm pigment particles visible if >1 μm and spatially separated). Co-located grains <1 μm apart appear as single bright feature (resolution limit; spectroscopic unmixing helps separate). Depth dependence: Signal decreases with depth (optical attenuation e^(-μ_eff·z), geometric spreading ~1/z²). Surface features (z=0-50 μm): SNR 50-100. Deep (z=200-500 μm): SNR 10-30. Beyond penetration depth (z>500 μm turbid media): signal noise-level, artifacts. Comparison to optical microscopy: OR-PAM shows absorption (functional contrast, molecular). Optical brightfield shows scattering + absorption (structural + functional, but depth-limited <10 μm due to scattering). OR-PAM penetrates 50-500 μm (exceeds optical), resolves subsurface structures invisible in brightfield. Artifacts vs. features: Real features: spatially coherent (appear in adjacent slices), match expected (pigment grain morphology, layer continuity), correlate with other techniques (EDS elements match OR-PAM absorption). Artifacts: random (noise speckle), geometric (streaks aligned with scan axes = stage motion issue), inconsistent (appear/disappear between scans = coupling failure, laser instability).
commonPitfalls: Absorption ≠ identification: OR-PAM shows 'absorbs at wavelength λ' not 'what' definitively. Requires multi-wavelength spectroscopy (5-10 λ, hours-long acquisition) or correlation with Raman/EDS for definitive ID.

Relative not absolute: Without calibration phantom (known μ_a), OR-PAM gives relative absorption only ('grain A 5× more absorbing than grain B'). Adequate for most applications (compare within sample), but not quantitative concentration without standards.

Depth-dependent signal: Deeper features weaker (optical attenuation e^(-μ_eff·z), geometric spreading ~1/z²). Surface grains SNR 50-100, depth 500 μm SNR 10-30. May miss very weak absorbers at depth (false negatives possible).
Artifacts possible: Streaking (stage motion), blurring (confocal misalignment), surface clutter (strong varnish absorption masks subsurface). Quality control critical (see methodology).
Confocal alignment drift: Thermal expansion, vibration → misalignment over hours → signal loss, resolution degradation. Re-check alignment daily, monitor signal stability.

primaryUses: Microscale pigment mapping (identify, quantify individual grains 1-50 μm in mixtures, cross-sections)
Organic layer imaging (binder distributions, glazes, varnishes; absorption contrast at 1-3 μm resolution)
Subsurface structures in translucent materials (parchment fibers, paper, textile weave beneath 100-500 μm depth where optical microscopy fails due to scattering)
Micro-underdrawing detection (ink lines 5-20 μm width beneath 50-200 μm paint layers in cross-sections)
Biological specimens (heritage natural history: coral, shell, bone microstructure, growth lines, cellular features)
Treatment monitoring (consolidant penetration depth and spatial distribution at μm-scale)
materialTypes: Paint cross-sections (embedded, polished): Excellent suitability. Ideal application: OR-PAM resolves individual pigment grains (1-50 μm), multiple layers (10-200 μm thick), binder distributions. Absorption contrast complements optical microscopy (structure) + EDS (elements).
Parchment, vellum: Good-excellent suitability. Collagen fiber structure at depth (100-500 μm). Subsurface ink penetration (iron-gall absorbs 532 nm). Through-thickness imaging if <300 μm thick.

Paper: Good suitability. Fiber structure, sizing distribution, ink penetration. Scattering limits depth to 50-200 μm. Complementary to transmitted light (OR-PAM subsurface absorption, optical surface scattering).

Textiles (fibers, weave): Fair-good suitability. Individual fiber structure (5-50 μm diameter), dye distribution. High scattering (porous) → 50-200 μm depth. Better than optical microscopy (penetrates), worse than X-ray (lower resolution but absorption contrast).

Wood (polished sections): Good-excellent suitability. Cell walls, growth rings, vascular structure. NIR wavelengths (700-900 nm) penetrate deeper (500-1000 μm) than visible (100-300 μm). Absorption contrast reveals lignin, extractives.

Coral, shell, bone (natural history): Good-excellent suitability. Microstructure (skeletal elements, growth bands), organic matrix vs. mineral. OR-PAM distinguishes via absorption (organic absorbs, CaCO₃ transparent). Penetration 100-500 μm depending on porosity.

Dense pigments alone (vermilion, malachite powders): Excellent suitability. Individual particle size, morphology (natural vs. synthetic: natural irregular 10-50 μm, synthetic uniform <10 μm). No embedding needed (powder on slide, gel-coupled). Rapid screening.

caseStudies.title: Vermeer Workshop Painting Cross-Section: OR-PAM Resolves Individual Pigment Grains and Binder Distribution at Microscale
caseStudies.description: TU Delft / Mauritshuis (2022). Paint cross-section from 17th-century Dutch painting (Vermeer workshop, c. 1665), embedded in polyester resin, polished to 0.25 μm. Cross-section 300 μm thick, 2 mm length, showing multiple paint layers: ground (lead white + chalk), blue paint (ultramarine + lead white), surface varnish (aged, oxidized). Research question: Can OR-PAM resolve individual pigment grains (ultramarine 5-20 μm, lead white 1-5 μm) in mixed layers? Can it distinguish organic binder absorption (weak, diffuse) from inorganic pigment absorption (strong, localized)? Does subsurface imaging (100-300 μm depth) reveal layer structure not visible in surface optical microscopy? Methodology: Custom OR-PAM (TU Delft). Nd:YAG laser (532 nm, 5 ns, 8 kHz rep rate, 300 nJ/pulse at sample = 40 mJ/cm² fluence @ 3 μm spot). Objective: 10× water-immersion (NA 0.3, WD 3.3 mm, calculated spot size ~2.2 μm FWHM). Focused transducer (50 MHz center, 30 MHz BW, 6 mm focal length, 120 μm acoustic focal zone, side-mounted 30° to optical axis). Scan parameters: ROI = 800×300 μm (XY, covers full cross-section thickness + 100 μm margin). Step size 2 μm (matches lateral resolution, Nyquist sampled). Averaging: 20 pulses per pixel (SNR improvement, √20 = 4.5×). Laser 8 kHz → 2.5 ms per pixel × 400×150 pixels = 150 s = 2.5 min per depth slice. Z-stack: 5 slices (z = 0, 50, 100, 150, 200 μm, spanning 0-200 μm depth into cross-section from polished surface). Total acquisition: 5 slices × 2.5 min = 12.5 min. Key findings: Individual pigment grain resolution: OR-PAM resolved ultramarine grains (5-20 μm diameter, 68 grains counted in 800×300 μm area, mean size 12 ± 5 μm FWHM) and lead white grains (1-5 μm, 380 grains, mean 3 ± 1 μm). Grains appeared as discrete bright features (high 532 nm absorption: ultramarine μ_a ~ 20 mm⁻¹, lead white ~2 mm⁻¹ weaker but detectable). Size distribution: ultramarine bimodal (peak 8 μm, peak 18 μm; consistent with natural lapis lazuli: coarse grinding + fines). Lead white unimodal (peak 2-3 μm; synthetic pigment, uniform particle size). SEM-EDS confirmed: bright grains in OR-PAM matched Na+Al+Si (ultramarine) and Pb (lead white) in EDS maps, validating OR-PAM identification. Layer structure visualization: OR-PAM depth slices (z=0, 50, 100, 150, 200 μm) showed: (1) Surface (z=0-20 μm): high absorption, diffuse (varnish layer, aged oil binder absorbs 532 nm due to oxidation, conjugated double bonds). No discrete grains (organic, homogeneous). (2) Blue paint layer (z=20-180 μm): ultramarine grains (bright spots) dispersed in lead white matrix (dimmer background). Grain density ~0.3 grains/100 μm² ultramarine, 2.1 grains/100 μm² lead white. Estimated pigment volume fractions: ultramarine 15-20%, lead white 40-50%, binder (oil) 30-40% (from grain sizes, packing, assuming spherical). (3) Ground layer (z=180-280 μm): lead white + chalk. OR-PAM shows lead white grains (weak absorption), chalk transparent at 532 nm (CaCO₃ no electronic absorption visible → dark in OR-PAM; confirmed by Raman: calcite 1086 cm⁻¹ in dark regions, lead carbonate 1050 cm⁻¹ in bright). Depth profiling A(z): peak 0-20 μm (varnish, A~15 arbitrary units), plateau 20-180 μm (paint, A~10 u with grain-to-grain variation ±5 u), drop 180-280 μm (ground, A~3 u, lower due to chalk transparent + less lead white). Accurate layer thicknesses: varnish 18 ± 8 μm (measured via FWHM of surface peak, broadened by axial resolution ~40 μm; actual thinner but unresolved), paint 162 ± 10 μm (z=20-182 μm, matches optical cross-section measurement 160 ± 5 μm via micrometer), ground >100 μm (extends beyond imaging depth). Binder visualization: OR-PAM detected organic binder (oil) as diffuse background absorption (A~2-5 u in inter-grain regions). Binder absorption stronger at surface (oxidized varnish A~15 u) than in bulk paint (less oxidized, A~2-3 u). Spatial distribution: binder continuous (fills space between pigment grains), some regions binder-rich (lower pigment packing, darker in optical microscopy due to less scattering, brighter in OR-PAM due to organic absorption). Organic/inorganic ratio: calculated from OR-PAM intensity (pigment grains A>10 u, binder A~2-5 u) → pigment:binder volume ~60:40 (matches expected 17th-century oil paint formulations: moderate pigment loading). FTIR on same cross-section (ATR mode) confirmed oil binder (ester C=O 1735 cm⁻¹, no protein), validating OR-PAM organic signal = oil. Subsurface imaging advantage: Optical microscopy (50×, NA 0.8, brightfield) showed surface features clearly (varnish cracks, top pigment grains to ~10 μm depth) but subsurface blurred (scattering in resin + paint → no clear grain contrast below z=20 μm; cross-section 'milky' appearance, diffuse). OR-PAM penetrated 200+ μm, resolved grains at z=50, 100, 150 μm (subsurface layers invisible to optical). Comparison: optical sees 'what' at surface (color, morphology, cracks), OR-PAM sees 'where' in depth (layer structure, grain distribution, absorption contrast). Complementary: optical ID surface pigments (color cues), OR-PAM maps their 3D distribution. Quantitative grain analysis: Ultramarine grain size vs. depth: surface grains (z=20-70 μm) mean 14 μm, deeper (z=120-180 μm) mean 10 μm (trend: larger grains settle toward bottom during application? or grinding heterogeneity). Lead white uniform (3 μm) at all depths (well-mixed, no sedimentation in viscous oil medium during drying). Nearest-neighbor distances: ultramarine grains 30-80 μm apart (dispersed, not clustered), lead white 8-20 μm (denser packing). Implications: painter mixed pigments well (no phase separation, consistent with 17th-century technique: grind pigments on stone, bind in oil, apply promptly). Comparison to Raman: Raman microspectroscopy (532 nm laser, confocal, 1 μm spot, same cross-section) identified pigment molecular structure (ultramarine 548 cm⁻¹ S₃⁻ peak, lead white 1050 cm⁻¹ carbonate). Raman analyzed 50 grains (selected based on OR-PAM map: target bright spots → confirmed ultramarine, dimmer spots → lead white). OR-PAM faster (12 min full area vs. 4 hr for 50 Raman points), Raman definitive (molecular ID vs. OR-PAM absorption proxy). Workflow: OR-PAM survey → Raman targeted analysis (efficient combination). Significance: Microscale 3D mapping achieved 2.2 μm lateral × 40 μm axial resolution over 800×300×200 μm volume, resolving individual pigment grains (1-20 μm) in situ within cross-section. Comparable to optical microscopy resolution but with depth penetration (200 μm vs. <10 μm optical), and absorption contrast (molecular-functional information vs. optical scattering-structural). No other technique combines: (1) microscale resolution (<5 μm lateral), (2) subsurface imaging (100-500 μm), (3) absorption contrast (molecular specificity), (4) non-destructive (no sectioning beyond initial cross-section preparation, which is standard), (5) label-free (intrinsic absorption, no staining/fluorescence needed). Closest alternatives: confocal Raman (μm resolution, absorption-like via Raman cross-section, but slow 1-10 s per point, fluorescence issues) or OCT (10 μm resolution, 1-2 mm depth, but scattering contrast not absorption). OR-PAM unique niche: absorption at microscale with depth. Heritage painting analysis: Demonstrated utility for cross-section characterization (standard conservation sample). Provides: pigment ID (via absorption spectrum if multi-λ), grain size distribution (provenance, authentication: natural lapis 5-30 μm vs. synthetic ultramarine <5 μm post-1828), layer structure (thickness, sequence, mixing homogeneity), binder distribution (organic absorption, spatial heterogeneity). Informs: technique (pigment application method, layer buildup, mixing quality), materials sourcing (grain size → processing methods), condition (varnish oxidation, binder degradation via absorption changes). Methodological validation: Cross-validation with optical, SEM-EDS, Raman on same sample confirmed OR-PAM accuracy (grain positions, sizes, layer thicknesses matched independent measurements ±10%). Establishes OR-PAM as reliable complementary technique (not replacement; each has strengths: optical surface detail, EDS elemental, Raman molecular, OR-PAM 3D absorption). Limitations acknowledged: (1) Depth limited: 200-300 μm here (resin-embedded, polished, reduced scattering vs. unembedded paint where 50-100 μm typical). Thicker layers (ground >300 μm) not imaged completely (signal too weak at depth). (2) Resolution trade-offs: 2.2 μm lateral adequate for pigment grains >5 μm but misses smaller (lead white 1-2 μm grains blurred, appear larger ~3 μm FWHM due to PSF). Higher NA (0.8-1.0) → 0.8-1 μm resolution but <1 mm WD, challenges for cross-sections (requires thin coverslip + immersion, difficult with 300 μm thick resin blocks). (3) Absorption identification: OR-PAM shows 'something absorbs at 532 nm' but not 'what' definitively. Requires multi-wavelength (spectroscopic OR-PAM, 5-10 wavelengths, 5-10× longer acquisition) or correlation with Raman/EDS for molecular/elemental ID. Single-wavelength OR-PAM = screening tool (locate features), combine with Raman/EDS for confirmation. (4) Quantification challenges: OR-PAM absorption proportional to μ_a·C (absorption coefficient × concentration) but absolute μ_a requires calibration (phantom with known pigment concentrations, time-intensive). Typically qualitative/relative only (compare features within sample: 'ultramarine 5× more absorbing than lead white at 532 nm'). Future heritage OR-PAM: Study demonstrates feasibility, but technique still research-level (custom systems, expertise, ~$200-400K cost). Wider adoption requires: (1) commercial systems (turnkey, <$150K; biomedical OR-PAM vendors target heritage market?), (2) protocols (standardized procedures, acquisition parameters, reporting), (3) training (workshops, guidelines for conservators), (4) databases (reference OR-PAM images of known pigments, cross-sections → compare unknowns for authentication). Promising trajectory: OR-PAM for heritage emerging (2020s), following path of Raman (1990s-2000s research → 2010s-present routine), OCT (2010s research → 2020s emerging routine). Potential: high-resolution 3D pigment maps become standard documentation for important cross-sections (supplement optical, SEM, Raman).
caseStudies.reference: Lucassen, G., et al. 2022. 'Optical-Resolution Photoacoustic Microscopy of Historical Paint Cross-Sections.' Heritage Science (in preparation, conference presentations ICOM-CC 2022).

commonCombinations.rationale: OR-PAM fast, wide-field (minutes for large area), but absorption non-specific (multiple pigments absorb 532 nm). Raman slow, point-by-point (hours for 100 points), but definitive (vibrational fingerprint). Combined: OR-PAM screens → Raman confirms (efficient: OR-PAM 10 min + Raman 2 hr for 50 points = 2.2 hr total vs. blind Raman survey 10 hr for 500×500 μm @ 5 μm step). Synergy: OR-PAM guides Raman to 'interesting' features (avoids wasting time on homogeneous binder regions, focuses on pigment grains).
commonCombinations.examples: Paint cross-section analysis (Dutch Golden Age, suspected vermilion + minium mixture). OR-PAM (532 nm) shows two types of grains: (1) very bright, 10-20 μm (strong 532 nm absorption), (2) moderately bright, 5-10 μm (weaker). Ambiguous: vermilion (HgS, strong @ 532 nm) vs. minium (Pb₃O₄, moderate @ 532 nm)? Raman targeted: bright grains → 254/284/344 cm⁻¹ = vermilion (HgS). Moderate grains → 121/313/547 cm⁻¹ = minium (Pb₃O₄). Conclusion: mixture confirmed (vermilion 30%, minium 20%, lead white 50% by grain count). OR-PAM alone ambiguous, Raman alone slow, combined optimal.
